text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Friday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- Ukrainian Foreign Minister Gennady Udovenko signed agreements with his Latvian counterpart on the promotion and protection of investments, mutual travel of citizens and the readmission of illegal migrants .

- Political paralysis continues - coalition parties have rejected the proposal of Prime Minister Andris Shkele to resolve the government crisis. Shkele admitted that his days at the helm may be numbered.

- The cabinet may adopt regulations in accordance with article 81 of the constitution to prevent the liquidator of bankrupt Banka Baltija from selling Ventspils' Nafta's debt to the bank to a Liechtenstein-based offshore company.
- The newspaper says that in the view of the coalition parties, a "stable government will be a new government."
- The Riga stock exchange celebrates its second anniversary today. The number of shares quoted on the bourse has grown to 45 from four.
- The interior ministry received 4,000 sets of portable drug detecting devices, granted by the U.S. government.
